College of Materials Science and Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 PR China Poor N2 selectivity and low SO2-tolerant are dominated weaknesses for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR) catalysts, which must be overcome for practical applications. Herein, a Mn-Fe mixed catalyst supported on active carbon (Mn-Fe/AC) for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO was prepared, and the influence of SO2 on this process was also studied. Both iron and sulfur dioxide exhibited a dual-acting over Mn-Fe/AC catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO. Sulfur dioxide had two effects when SO2 was introduced in the feed gas under SCR conditions, including inhibiting the low temperature activity of the catalysts and improving N2 selectivity which exceeded 90% during the whole testing temperature. The introduction of SO2 could promote the formation of NH2NO which was the main intermediate and then decomposed into N2. Fe species in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst could improve N2 selectivity. In the presence of SO2, it showed considerable SO2 resistance compared to Mn/AC catalyst. On the one hand, iron species improved the selectivity through forming new active sites promoting the formation of NH2NO and suppressing the free NO3 - generation. On the other hand, iron existing in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst could decrease the amount of sulfur species adsorbent and SO2 oxidation, thereby exhibiting better SO2 resistance. Graphical Abstract Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Low-temperature NH3-SCR Dual-acting of SO2 Mn-Fe supported on active carbon N2 selectivity 1 Introduction The importance of the low temperature selective catalytic reduction of nitric oxides (NO x ) with NH3 (SCR) is increasing by reason of the recent severe pollution regulations being imposed around the world. Catalyst supports and mixed transition metal oxides for low-temperature SCR have been widely investigated, however, these low-temperature catalysts still have some drawbacks, especially in terms of low N2 selectivity and catalyst poisoning by H2O or/and SO2 [1–3]. Hence, the development of catalysts for the low-temperature SCR process is still under active investigation throughout seeking better catalytic performance. Mn-containing catalysts show outstanding catalytic activity in low temperature because of the easy gain and loss of electrons in the d shell responsible for the facile redox properties [1,2]. Nevertheless, manganese-containing catalysts for SCR process suffer from unexpectedly poor N2 selectivity, which is mainly resulted from the excessive activation of N-H bands [4]. Also, these catalysts are easily inactivated in the existing of SO2 in the feed and exhibit low N2 selectivity, which are in accordance with our previous studies [5,6]. Both shortcomings restrain the practical applications of Mn-containing catalysts. Generally, it is accepted that NH4 + adsorbed on Brønsted acid site (B-NH3) and NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (L-NH3) are anticipated to be essential for the reaction mechanism [2,7]. Furthermore, the formations of intermediates of NH2NO and NH4NO2 are the key steps and then following by decomposing to N2 and H2O [2,7–10]. While N2O mainly derives from the decomposition of NH4NO3 intermediate via the reaction between free NO3 - and adsorbed NH3, as well as NH3 oxidation [2,8]. For SO2 resistance, reducing the adsorption/oxidation of SO2 is regarded as a main step for improving the SO2 tolerance of catalysts in low temperature SCR process [2,3,11]. As mentioned above, poor N2 selectivity and low SO2-tolerance are main weaknesses which must be overcome for practical application. Herein, in an earlier study, we found MnO x loaded on carbon-based support showed remarkable NO conversion among CeO x , VO x and FeO x containing catalysts, whereas exhibiting poor N2 selectivity [12]. In an attempt to improve the excessive oxidation of MnO x , we prepared a series of Mn-containing mixed oxides supported on carbon-based materials [13–15]. These catalysts exhibited considerable SCR activity and some SO2/H2O-tolerance, but still poor N2 selectivity during the standard NH3-SCR. Specially, these catalysts showed an improvement in N2 selectivity in the presence of SO2. On this basis, we prepared a Mn-Fe mixed catalyst supported on active carbon (Mn-Fe/AC) for low-temperature SCR of NO and studied the effects of SO2 and Fe existing. It was found that iron and sulfur dioxide conducted a dual-acting over Mn-Fe/AC catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO, in which sulfur dioxide would suppress the low-temperature activity and also improve the N2 selectivity. Fe species in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst could improve N2 selectivity. In the presence of SO2, it showed considerable SO2 resistance compared to Mn/AC catalyst. Importantly, the positive effects of SO2 in NH3-SCR process are rarely studied on the carbon-based catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts were prepared by impregnation of AC (Xinhua Chemical Plant, calcination in N2 at 400 °C for 4 h) with Mn(NO3)2 and/or Fe(NO3)3•9H2O as precursors to obtain a nominal composition of 5 wt% metal oxide loading. The mixed solution was remained at 50 °C for 8 h and then the samples were dried at 90 °C for 12 h. Calcination in N2 at 400 °C for 4 h was performed after impregnation. The AC was also calcined with the metal doping catalysts for avoiding the influence of variable factors. The obtained catalysts were marked as M/AC, M stands for Mn and/or Fe, where the mole ratio of Mn/Fe was 1:1. The detailed preparation methods of all catalysts are given in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.2 Catalytic performance The SCR activity of catalysts was tested in a fixed-bed quartz reaction under the following conditions: 500 ppm of NH3, 500 ppm of NO, 100 ppm of SO2 (when used), 11% of O2 and N2 as balance at a total flow rate of 300/500/1000 mL/min. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 12,000/20,000/40,000 h-1. The outlet gasses concentrations were measured by a flue gas analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Antaris IGS) and the data were recorded after the system remaining stable for 20 min at each desired temperature. The NO conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated according to the following equations: (S1) N O conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n ) × 100 % (S2) N 2 selectivity = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 % Where the subscripts in and out indicated the inlet and outlet concentration at steady state, respectively. More detailed experimental parameters, the computational method, and catalyst characterization were also given in the SI. Infrared (IR) spectra range and assignment of surface species during in situ DRIFTS experiments were shown in Table 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance 3.1.1 Catalytic activity of NH3-SCR The NO conversion (Eqs. (S1)) and N2 selectivity (Eqs. (S2)) of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were shown in Fig. 1 . For Mn/AC catalyst, between 100 and 300 °C, NO conversion was always above 80%, and it displayed the highest activity of 90% at 200 °C. After Fe doping, the NO conversion of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst increased a bit compared to that of Mn/AC catalyst, which was more obvious during higher temperature between 200 and 300 °C, also exhibiting the highest activity of 95% at 200 °C. Notely, Fe/AC catalyst showed much better NO reduction performance between 200 and 300 °C than that between 75 and 175 °C. Hence, it could be inferred that the Fe species might mainly contribute to relatively high temperature activity. In the process of NH3-SCR, ammonia could be oxidized directly at high temperature over Mn containing catalysts, which was studied in one previous paper [5]. With the increasing temperature, the N2O amount and the N2O generation ratio from NH3 oxidation of MnO x both increased. Therefore, for Mn/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts, the NO conversion was decreased above 200 °C, while Fe/AC sample showed consistent NO conversion above 200 °C. The production of N2O was observed (Fig. S1), but no production of NO2. The N2 selectivity in Fig. 1 for all the catalysts decreased with the temperature increasing between 75 and 300 °C, while that of Mn/AC catalyst showed the poorest and Fe/AC catalyst exhibited the best N2 selectivity, which was also in line with the literatures [2]. After bimetallic doping, the Mn-Fe/AC catalyst conducted better N2 selectivity than that of Mn/AC catalyst but worse than that of Fe/AC catalyst. In case of the three catalysts, the maximum N2 selectivity at 75 °C of 96% and 300 °C of 68% was found for Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, while also at 75 °C of 94% and 300 °C of 43% for Mn/AC catalyst and at 75 °C of 93% and 300 °C of 85% for Fe/AC catalyst. Beside, the conversion of NO dropped off upon increasing the GHSV (Fig. S2), which indicated that Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were limited by mass transfer during SCR process. 3.1.2 Influence of SO2 In an attempt to investigate the SO2 influence during NH3-SCR process on the catalytic activity, SO2 was introduced in the feed gas, as shown in Fig. 2 . The SO2 introducing impaired the deNO x efficiency especially at low temperatures, reducing the deNO x rate of Mn/AC catalyst from 71% to 24%, Fe/AC catalyst from 32% to 25% and Mn-Fe/AC catalyst from 74% to 35% at 100 °C, respectively. The NO conversion of Mn/AC catalyst suffered the most obvious decline during the whole testing temperature compared to that of Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts, showing apparent changes of the curve shape, while the curve tendency of Fe/AC catalyst almost remained the same as before. Compared to Mn/AC catalyst, Fe doping could partly weaken the SO2 influence during NH3-SCR process in the low temperature region. The reason might be that SO2 could interact with Fe species to form new active sites contributing to the SCR activity, which was observed in other literatures [26,27]. Mn species dominated the low temperature activity of Mn containing catalysts, but the Mn species was easily inactivated due to SO2 poisoning. Specially, deNO x efficiency of the three catalysts also suffered severer decline in the low temperature region than that of high temperature region. Interestingly, the N2 selectivity of the three catalysts all obtained a significantly improvement, reaching above 90% during the whole testing temperature, which meant different reactions and/or intermediates were appeared when SO2 existed. This would be discussed in the following parts. 3.2 Morphology and structure of the catalysts Fe containing catalysts of Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC showed better N2 selectivity and sulfur resistance ( Figs. 1 and 2 ). Some characterizations were conducted to have an insight into the difference between these catalysts. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis on Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts indicated that the contents of manganese and iron corresponded well to their nominal values (Table S1), revealing the approximately the same amount of active component. It could avoid the activity difference caused by different content of active substances. As calculated in the form of oxidation state, Mn/AC catalyst contained 4.49 wt% MnO2, Fe/AC catalyst contained 4.71 wt% Fe2O3, and Mn-Fe/AC catalyst contained 2.37 wt% MnO2 and 2.31 wt% Fe2O3. To compare the activity of the catalysts on a surface basis, the BET data of these catalysts were measured (Table S2). The specific surface area of AC was 941 m2•g-1, while the specific surface area of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were 847, 820 and 811 m2•g-1, respectively. The specific surface area difference of these catalysts was less than 5%, as does the pore volume (Table S2). Therefore, the specific surface area of these catalysts was non considered to dominate the catalytic activity for NH3-SCR of NO. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images in Figs. 3 a–d and S3–S7 showed the morphologies of the catalysts. The surface seemed similar based on the large scale, also showing large number of irregular particles and rich pore structures on the surface ( Fig. 3 ). In order to detect more detailed surface characteristics, the magnified images were also presented in the corresponding images. The surface of Mn/AC catalyst was smooth as well as the surface of AC (Figs. S3 and S4), which indicated that Mn loading had little change compared with the AC support. Energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) mapping showed that the concentration of Mn on the surface was very high (Fig. S4 c and Table S1). Considering that the sampling depth of EDS mapping was about 1 μm, Mn was considered to be uniformly loaded on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst. For Fe/AC catalyst, a large number of tiny particles appeared on the surface (Figs. S5 and S6), which showed a great difference compared with the surface of AC and Mn/AC catalyst. The tiny particles were about 20 nm in size for Fe/AC catalyst, which were evenly distributed on the surface (Figs. S5 and S6). The results of EDS spot and surface scanning both indicated that these tiny particles were iron species (Fig. S5d), which was considered due to the agglomeration caused by the calcination process. For Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, the surface was similar to that of Fe/AC catalyst, and a large number of tiny particles appeared as well (Fig. S7). The tiny particles were not uniform in size and there was agglomeration for Mn-Fe/AC catalyst (Fig. S7c). The results of EDS surface scanning indicated the uniform dispersion of active substances on the surface (Fig. S7b), while EDS spot scanning indicated these tiny particles were iron and Mn species (Fig. S7 d and e). Therefore, Fe and Mn species were considered existing as tiny particles on the surface of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 . The (0 0 2) diffraction peak located at 20–30° represented the existence of graphite crystallite with layered structure also implying graphitization degree, while the (1 0 0) diffraction peak located at 40–45° reflected the turbostratic graphite-like structure corresponding to the aromatic molecule size [26,27]. AC support without any active component was calcined together with Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts for avoiding the influence of variable factors. After metal oxides species loading, the intensity of (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) diffraction peaks declined apparently, which indicated the degree of aromatization and the aromatic planar molecular size were influenced by doping metal oxides. Beside, no diffraction peaks corresponding to the crystalline phase of manganese oxides or iron oxides appeared on the XRD patterns of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts, which might be due to the low loading amount of metal oxides. Another reason could be that Mn, Fe and Mn-Fe mixed oxides dispersed well on the AC surface and/or had a lower degree of crystallinity. Combined with SEM results (Fig. S7), the most possible reason might be due to the amorphous state of Mn and Fe species. 3.3 Surface properties of the catalysts NH3 adsorption at 40 °C and temperature programmed desorption/reaction (TPDR) tests were performed, and the corresponding results were reported in Fig. 5 and Table S2. Mn-Fe/AC catalyst showed higher amount of NH3 adsorption than that of Mn/AC and Fe/AC catalysts, which were 2.73 mmol•g-1 of Mn/AC, 2.77 mmol•g-1 of Fe/AC and 2.95 mmol•g-1 of Mn-Fe/AC (Table S2), respectively. With temperature programmed desorption, more NH3 was released on Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, which was corresponding to 0.45 mmol•g-1 (Table S2) which was lower than the adsorbed amount of NH3. This indicated that part of the adsorbed NH3 might react with the support to form intermediates. Beside, nearly no other gasses resulted from the adsorbed NH3 were detected during the temperature program between 40 and 600 °C. A certain amount CO was tested at around 400 °C, which was mainly due to the decomposition of oxygen containing group (C=O, O-H, C-O and C-O-C) [12,28–31]. Moreover, AC support without any active component was also conducted the NH3-TPDR for comparison to avoid extra influence ( Fig. 5 a). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique was applied to identify the state of the elements on the surface of catalysts and surface element concentrations of the catalysts, with the results shown in Figs. 6 and S8. Fig. 6 a displayed the C 1s spectra, which could be well fitted into three characteristic peaks at around 288.48–288.94 eV, 284.34–284.57 eV and 283.39–283.49 eV, assigning to carbonyl C (C=O) and/or carboxyl C (O-C=O), sp2 C (C=C) and graphitic C (C–C) [28–31], respectively. The peak areas of C1s spectra were also shown in Fig. 6 a and Table S1. C–C and C=C were the main composition in the AC support catalysts. The O 1s spectra of the catalysts were presented in Fig. 6 b. The O 1s spectra of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts could be well fitted into three characteristic peaks, corresponding to M-O groups (529.33–530.06 eV), C-OH and/or C-O-C groups (531.98–532.35 eV) and C=O groups (534.63–535.17 eV) [31]. The O 1s spectra of AC could be well fitted into two characteristic peaks assigned to C-OH and/or C-O-C groups (98–532.35 eV) and C=O groups (534.63–535.17 eV). The content of different oxygen species calculated by the XPS results was presented in Table S1. Fig. 6 c displayed the Mn 2p spectra, which contained two main peaks at around 653.0 eV and 641.2 eV, assigning to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2, respectively [32,33]. The Mn 2p3/2 peaks of Mn/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts could be fitted into three characteristic peaks at 644.19–644.55 eV, 641.15–641.32 eV and 639.76–639.78 eV, which were corresponding to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+, respectively [32,33]. Mn3+ was the main manganese species in Mn/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts (Table S1). Mn-Fe/AC catalyst showed higher concentration of Mn2+ than that of Mn/AC catalyst. Fe spectra contained two distinguishable peaks consistent with Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 ( Fig. 6 d). Both of the Fe 2p3/2 peak of Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts could be well fitted into two peaks, indicating the existence of two Fe species, Fe3+ (711.06–711.56 eV) and Fe2+ (709.37–709.60 eV) [32]. The Fe3+ atomic ratio of Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were 48% and 65%, respectively (Table S1). 3.4 Insight into the dual-acting of iron and sulfur dioxide 3.4.1 Insight into the SO2 adsorption In order to reveal the adsorption capacity and the types of the sulfates generated on the surface during the SO2 + O2 adsorption, the SO2 and O2 adsorption/stability process should be clarified. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) spectra of SO2+O2 adsorption and desorption over Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were investigated ( Fig. 7 ). After pretreatment of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts with 100 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% O2 for 30 min at 50 °C, the DRIFTS spectra bands appeared at ∼x223C1375, ∼x223C1358 and ∼x223C1347 cm–1 were observed, which were ascribed to surface sulfate (M–SO4 2–), surface adsorbed SO2 and absorption vibration peak of sulfite (M–SO3 2–), respectively [17–19]. The normalized IR intensities of all bands of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts increased with the increasing adsorption time at 50 °C. Specially, two adjacent peaks including a positive band at ∼x223C1268 cm–1 and a negative band at ∼x223C1250 cm–1 were observed on Mn-Fe/AC catalyst ( Fig. 7 c1). Note that negative and positive absorbance values indicated consumption and formation of species, respectively. For Mn/AC catalyst, the SO2 adsorption was detected from ∼x223C1.5 min and attained adsorption saturation after ∼x223C9.4 min ( Fig. 7 a3). For Fe/AC catalyst, SO2 adsorption peaks were found from ∼x223C2.5 min and attained adsorption saturation after ∼x223C8.4 min ( Fig. 7 b3), while the SO2 adsorption on Mn-Fe/AC catalyst was observed from ∼x223C2.9 min and attained adsorption saturation after ∼x223C7.2 min ( Fig. 7 c3). This implied that SO2 could more easily adsorbed on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst than that of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, also partly indicating the bigger amount of sulfur species generation on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst. Or sulfur reacted with Mn species more easily. This again proved that more sulfur would form on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst. With the respect to the stability of surface sulfur species, temperature programming under in situ DRIFTS was applied to analyze the stability of different type of sulfur species on the surface of Mn/AC, Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts ( Fig. 7 a2–c2). The normalized IR intensities of all bands for Mn/AC catalyst showed a steady decline with the temperature increasing from 50 to 300 °C ( Fig. 7 a2 and 9 a1). The intensity of three main peaks on Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts showed relatively small change from 50 to 300 °C. While two small peaks located at ∼x223C1420 and ∼x223C1396 cm–1 assigned to SO3 like species for Mn-Fe/AC catalyst were found at 300 °C ( Fig. 7 c2 and 9 a2). Furthermore, Mn/AC catalyst showed a bit higher oxidation for SO2 than that of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst (Fig. S10). The sulfur species formed on Fe/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were more stable than that on Mn/AC catalyst. This might be the reason that Mn/AC and Mn-Fe/AC catalysts were severely inactivated due to SO2 poisoning, especially at low temperatures. 3.5.2 Insight into the SCR reaction To confirm the intermediate species formed on the catalyst surface under the reaction condition, a flow of NH3 + NO + O2 gas was introduced into the catalysts and the DRIFTS spectra were recorded at 50 °C, with the results shown in Fig. 8 . Furthermore, desorption experiments as a function of temperature from 50 to 250 °C with the feed gas were also carried out, with the results shown in Fig. 8 . At relatively low temperatures, most of the intermediate species would exist stable and could be well detected by the IR spectra [2,9]. As was known, the intermediate species formed during the SCR reaction were sensitive to temperature, including the NH4NO3, NH2NO, NH4NO2 and NH3NO species [2]. Therefore, we designed the low temperature adsorption experiments of NH3 + NO + O2 to identify the intermediate formed during the NH3-SCR of NO process. With the temperature programming between 50 and 250 °C, we focused on the peak changes of different intermediates to make clear the dual-acting of iron and sulfur dioxide. For SO2 resistance, it had inhibiting effect on the catalyst activity especially on Mn-containing catalysts at low temperature between 75 and 200 °C and unexpected positive effect on N2 selectivity for all the three catalysts. For iron doping in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, it could obviously increase the N2 selectivity and also showed considerable sulfur resistant during NH3-SCR process. For Mn/AC catalyst, when introducing NH3 + NO + O2 flow to the sample at 50 °C, the bands located at ∼x223C1907, ∼x223C1845, ∼x223C1746, ∼x223C1694 and ∼x223C1452 cm–1 were consistent with the asymmetric bending vibration of NH4 + adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites, while the band observed at ∼x223C1602 cm–1 was attributed to the symmetric bending vibrations of the N-H bond in coordinated NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites ( Figs. 8 a1, S13 and Table 1 ). Beside, the broad peak at 3500–3000 cm–1 was assigned to N–H stretching vibration of coordinated NH3 (Fig. S13) [22]. Also, bidentate bridging nitrate ((M-O)2-NO) (∼x223C1694 cm–1), NO2 molecules (∼x223C1629 cm–1), bidentate chelating nitrate (M-O2NO) (∼x223C1540 cm–1) and monodentate nitrate (M-O-NO2) (∼x223C1516 cm–1) were detected on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst ( Fig. 8 a1 and Table 1 ). Beside, a wide band at 1400–1317 cm–1 was observed and could be attribute to antisymmetric N–O stretches (free NO3 -) [9,20,21]. Generally, the co-existence of NH4 + and NO3 - (1380 cm-1) implied the NH4NO3 formation, which then decomposed to N2O and H2O [8,10,34]. With a temperature program, the L-NH3 species gradually reduced, while all the B-NH3 species declined but subsequent increased ( Figs. 8 a2 and S13 b). Also, the intensity of bands at ∼x223C1540 and ∼x223C1516 cm–1 attributed to bidentate chelating nitrate (M-O2NO) and monodentate nitrate (M-O-NO2) declined and subsequent increased. Combined with the SCR activity results ( Fig. 1 ), Mn/AC catalyst exhibited quite low N2 selectivity at higher temperature, which might result from the high content of NO3 - species. For Fe/AC catalyst, NH4 + adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites and coordinated NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites were observed. While bidentate bridging nitrate, NO2 molecules, bidentate chelating nitrate, monodentate nitrate and free NO3 - were detected on the surface of Fe/AC catalyst (Fig. S11 a and Table 1 ). The intermediates appeared on Fe/AC catalyst was similar to Mn/AC catalyst, but a new peak at ∼x223C1490 cm–1 belonging to nitrosamide intermediate (NH2NO, v(NO)) was detected on Fe/AC catalyst. With the temperature increasing, all peak intensity decreased (Fig. S11 b and Table 1 ). While the free NO3 - and M -NO2 appeared at relative high temperatures. As for Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, similar IR bands appeared on the surface as present on Mn/AC and Fe/AC catalysts, NH4 + adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (∼x223C1907, ∼x223C1837, ∼x223C1760, ∼x223C1696 and ∼x223C1460 cm–1), NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (∼x223C1603 cm–1), bidentate bridging nitrate (∼x223C1665 cm–1), adsorbed NH3 (3500–3000 cm–1), NO2 molecules (∼x223C1626 cm–1), monodentate nitrate (∼x223C1530 cm–1), monodentate nitrate (M-O-NO2) (∼x223C1516 cm–1) and free NO3 - (∼x223C1400–1317 cm–1) were all detected on its surface with the increasing of adsorption time ( Figs. 8 c1 and S15). Significantly, one new peak at ∼x223C1490 cm–1 belonging to NH2NO that was also observed on Fe/AC catalyst was detected compared with that of Mn/AC catalyst (Fig. S17), which would decompose to N2 and H2O [7,25]. With temperature increasing from 50 to 250 °C, except free NO3 - species, all adsorbed species declined and even disappeared at 150 oC ( Fig. 8 c2 and 9 d2), indicating free NO3 - could exist steadily and the other species vanished were sensitive to the high temperature. 3.4.3 Insight into the SCR + SO2 reaction To further investigate the SO2 effects on the NH3-SCR reaction, SO2 was introduced into the flow of NH3 + NO + O2 and the DRIFTS spectra were recorded at 50 oC ( Figs. 8 b1 and 8 d1, S12 a and S14 a). Beside, subsequent desorption as a function of temperature from 50 to 250 oC with the feed gas was also carried out ( Figs. 8 b2 and 8 d2, S12 b and S14 b). The bands presented on the Mn/AC catalyst were almost the same as that under the NH3 + NO + O2 flow. Specially, a new peak at ∼x223C1490 cm–1 combining with NH2NO was observed [7,25]. With the temperature increasing from 50 to 250 oC, the changes occurred on the surface of Mn/AC catalyst were totally different from that under the NH3 + NO + O2 flow but similar to that of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst ( Fig. 8 b2 and c2). Except the free NO3 - species, all adsorbed species declined and even disappeared at 150 oC, while band at ∼x223C1262 cm–1 ascribed to M-NO2 and NO2 molecules appeared. For Fe/AC catalyst, the peak corresponding to NH2NO species was much bigger than that under the NH3 + NO + O2 flow (Fig. S12 a), while the peak (∼x223C1430 cm–1) combining with B-NH3 and peak of M-NO2 were stronger with temperature increasing (Fig. S12 b). For Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, the bands presented on surface were similar to that of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst under NH3-SCR condition ( Fig. 8 c1 and d1), while the peak corresponding to NH2NO species was much bigger than that under the NH3 + NO + O2 flow ( Fig. 8 d1). With the temperature program, all bands declined and even disappeared at 150 oC, except the peak (∼x223C1430 cm–1) combining with B-NH3 ( Fig. 8 d2). Specially, one new peak at ∼x223C1256 cm–1 belonging to M-NO2 remained the same when the temperature increased from 150 to 250 oC. As shown on Figs. 8 and 9 , most peaks belonging to oxynitride species obeyed the similar behavior with the function of both temperature and adsorption time. While some vital peaks such as B-NH3 (NH4NO3), free NO3 - (NH4NO3), NH2NO and L-NH3 showed some differences based on the different metal oxides and reaction condition. Typically, the (M-O)2-NO), NO2 molecules, M-O2NO and M-O-NO2 species on the surface of catalysts showed no obvious changes, which indicated that these adsorbed species were not the dominated factors on the deNO x rate and N2 selectivity. Interestingly, with the existing of SO2 and/or Fe species, the NH2NO also presented on the surface of catalysts, which might be the main reason for the improvement of N2 selectivity. It inferred that adsorbed SO2 and Fe species could come into being new active sites and contributing to the NH2NO formation. Beside, the NH3-TPDR gave the evidence of more adsorbed NH3 on Mn-Fe/AC catalyst (Table S2). Combined with the SEM results ( Figs. 3 c and d, S7), the tiny particles associated to Fe-Mn species on the surface of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst might provide the main additional active sites for high N2 selectivity. Additionally, between the different conditions of adsorption (Fig. S17), it could hardly find the peaks belonging to sulfur species with IR signal, which revealed SO2 might not be adsorbed on the catalysts as sulfur-containing species. Furthermore, two small peaks ascribed to weakly absorbed NH3 or gas-phase NH3 (966 and 930 cm–1) showed apparent decline with SO2 existing below 200 oC (Fig. S17) [22]. This might explain the low NO conversion with the SO2 existing, the NH3 adsorption amount dominated the activity of catalysts in low temperature range and part of the acid sites might be occupied by SO2, which then induced the low NO conversion. In higher temperature, the adsorbed NH3 on strong acid sites like metal species dominated the activity. In summary, the dual-acting of iron and sulfur dioxide over Mn-Fe/AC catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO was unraveled, and possible mechanism was proposed ( Fig. 10 ). For Mn/AC catalyst, the Mn species were uniformly loaded on the surface. It showed high NO conversion, while the N2 selectivity increased with the temperature increasing. At higher temperatures, side reactions and direct oxidation of ammonia dominated, leading to the formation of large amount of N2O. Beside, adsorbed NH3 reacted with NO to form intermediates that were mainly NH4NO3 species. In the presence of SO2 in the feed gas, the NO conversion of Mn/AC catalyst decreased significantly, especially at low temperatures. The reason might be that Mn species was combined with sulfur and poisoned, which could not be new active sites. From the SO2 desorption experiments, the peaks corresponding to sulfur species decreased with the increase of temperature, which implied that SO2 could form competitive adsorption with NH3 at low temperature and then suppressing the low-temperature activity of Mn/AC catalyst, but it showed little effect on higher temperature stage. While SO2 existing could assist the formation of new active sites that contributed to the formation of NH2NO intermediate, which then decomposed to N2 and H2O and improved the N2 selectivity. For Mn-Fe/AC catalyst, Fe and Mn species were considered existing as tiny particles with a low degree of crystallinity on the surface. Mn-Fe/AC catalyst showed higher amount of NH3 adsorption than that of Mn/AC and Fe/AC catalysts. Mn-Fe/AC catalyst adsorbed less amount of SO2, and Fe doping could partly weaken the SO2 influence during NH3-SCR process in the low temperature region. The reason might be that SO2 could interact with Fe species to form new active sites contributing to the SCR activity, which could be stable on the surface. After bimetallic doping, the Mn-Fe/AC catalyst conducted better N2 selectivity than that of Mn/AC catalyst, which was due to iron doping changes the oxidation of manganese and formed new active sites promoting the formation of NH2NO intermediate. The presence of iron also attenuated the oxidation of sulfur dioxide by the catalyst, and the adsorption amount of sulfur dioxide on the surface also decreased. In the presence of SO2 in the feed gas, the peak corresponding to NH2NO species was much bigger than that under the NH3 + NO + O2 flow ( Fig. 8 d1), suggesting the presence of a large amount of NH2NO intermediate. It inferred that adsorbed SO2 and Fe species could come into being new active sites and contributing to the NH2NO formation. Regarding Fe species, it could not only improve the selectivity but also show considerable SO2 resistant. On one hand, iron species improved the N2 selectivity, which could conduct as new active sites and then form NH2NO intermediate. On the other hand, iron existing could decrease the adsorption amount of sulfur species and oxidation SO2, thereby exhibiting better SO2 resistant. Sulfur dioxide conducted as a dual-acting including suppressing the low-temperature activity of catalysts and improving the N2 selectivity. 4 Conclusion Mn-Fe mixed catalyst improved SCR activity and impressed SO2 resistant. Both iron and sulfur dioxide conducted a dual-acting over Mn-Fe/AC catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO. Fe and Mn species were considered existing as tiny particles on the surface of Mn-Fe/AC catalyst. It also showed higher amount of NH3 adsorption than that of Mn/AC and Fe/AC catalysts. Sulfur dioxide conducted as dual-acting including suppressing the low-temperature SCR activity and improving the N2 selectivity. The presence of SO2 could assist the formation of NH2NO contributing higher N2 selectivity. Fe species could not only improve the N2 selectivity but also show considerable SO2 resistant. On the one hand, iron species conducted as new active sites and improved the formation of NH2NO intermediate, which improved the N2 selectivity and declined the generation of free NO3 -. On the other hand, iron existing could decrease the adsorption amount of sulfur species and SO2 oxidation, thereby exhibiting better SO2 resistant . coredata.dc:description: Poor N2 selectivity and low SO2-tolerant are dominated weaknesses for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR) catalysts, which must be overcome for practical applications. Herein, a Mn-Fe mixed catalyst supported on active carbon (Mn-Fe/AC) for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO was prepared, and the influence of SO2 on this process was also studied. Both iron and sulfur dioxide exhibited a dual-acting over Mn-Fe/AC catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO. Sulfur dioxide had two effects when SO2 was introduced in the feed gas under SCR conditions, including inhibiting the low temperature activity of the catalysts and improving N2 selectivity which exceeded 90% during the whole testing temperature. The introduction of SO2 could promote the formation of NH2NO which was the main intermediate and then decomposed into N2. Fe species in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst could improve N2 selectivity. In the presence of SO2, it showed considerable SO2 resistance compared to Mn/AC catalyst. On the one hand, iron species improved the selectivity through forming new active sites promoting the formation of NH2NO and suppressing the free NO3 - generation. On the other hand, iron existing in Mn-Fe/AC catalyst could decrease the amount of sulfur species adsorbent and SO2 oxidation, thereby exhibiting better SO2 resistance.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding the dual-acting of iron and sulfur dioxide over Mn-Fe/AC catalysts for low-temperature SCR of NO
